revision.text:
{{update|date=September 2010}} [[File:Birmingham Selfridges building.jpg|thumb|upright|Selfridges at the Bullring.]] The '''Big City Plan''' is a major development plan for the [[city centre]] of [[Birmingham]], [[England]]. Stage 2 of the Big City Plan, the '''City Centre Masterplan''' was launched on 29 September 2010. This masterplan sets out how the city centre of Birmingham will be improved over the next 20 years. The plan identifies five key areas of development potentially worth £10 billion.[http://www.architectsjournal.co.uk/news/daily-news/mixed-reactions-to-birminghams-big-city-plan/8606409.article#Scene_1 Architects Journal Overview of Masterplan] The aim of this ambitious plan will be to increase the size of the city core by 25%, improving transport connectivity throughout the seven ‘quarters’ that make up the city centre. It identifies how the city centre population will grow providing more than 5000 new homes and 50,000 new jobs, as well as the £600 million redevelopment of [[Birmingham New Street railway station|New Street station]], opened in September 2015, a new [[Library of Birmingham]] which opened in September 2013 and [[Eastside City Park]] which was opened in 2012,http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/eastsidepark the first new city centre park since Victorian times.{{Cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.net/news/top-stories/2010/09/30/work-to-start-on-13m-green-oasis-in-birmingham-city-centre-97319-27368751/2|title=Birmingham Mail report on Stage 2|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101003074645/http://www.birminghammail.net/news/top-stories/2010/09/30/work-to-start-on-13m-green-oasis-in-birmingham-city-centre-97319-27368751/2/|archivedate=2010-10-03|df=}} It also sets out visionary proposals in which each of the seven 'quarters' will be able to evolve. ==Origins== [[File:BirminghamCentralLibrary.jpg|thumb|[[Birmingham Central Library]].]] The city was subject to a widespread regeneration effort following the [[Birmingham Blitz]] during [[World War II]]. This public demand for modern buildings, combined with Victorian architectural styles falling out of favour, resulted in dozens of fine Victorian buildings like the intricate glass-roofed [[Birmingham New Street railway station|Birmingham New Street station]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/GenerateContent?CONTENT_ITEM_ID=89806&CONTENT_ITEM_TYPE=0&MENU_ID=10277 |publisher=Birmingham City Council |title=Aerial View of New Street Station 1963 |accessdate=2007-09-23 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930221007/http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/GenerateContent?CONTENT_ITEM_ID=89806&CONTENT_ITEM_TYPE=0&MENU_ID=10277 |archivedate = 2007-09-30}} and the old Central Library being destroyed in the 1950s and 1960s by the city planners.{{cite web|url=http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/GenerateContent?CONTENT_ITEM_ID=46357&CONTENT_ITEM_TYPE=0&MENU_ID=260 |publisher=Birmingham City Council |title=Central Library - from old to new |accessdate=2007-09-23 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070702174842/http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/GenerateContent?CONTENT_ITEM_ID=46357&CONTENT_ITEM_TYPE=0&MENU_ID=260 |archivedate = 2007-07-02}} These planning decisions were to have a profound effect on the image of Birmingham in subsequent decades, with the mix of concrete [[ring road]]s, [[shopping mall|shopping centres]] and [[tower block]]s giving Birmingham a 'concrete jungle' tag.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2701829.stm |title=Tackling congestion in Birmingham |publisher=BBC News |date=2003-02-13 |accessdate=2007-09-23 |first=Louise |last=Scrivens}} Sir [[Herbert Manzoni]] was made city engineer of Birmingham and his work included the construction of the [[A4400 road|Inner Ring Road]], [[A4540 road|Middle Ring Road]] and the [[A4040 road|Outer Ring Road]], which necessitated the purchase and clearance of vast areas of land. As well as this, he designated large areas of land redevelopment areas and set about clearing large areas of slums.{{cite web|url=http://www.gees.bham.ac.uk/research/cpp/membersfiles/phil/biggerbetter.pdf |title=Bigger is Better? Local authority housing and the strange attraction of high-rise, 1945-70 |author=Phil Jones, Urban Morphology Research Group |year=2002 |publisher=University of Birmingham |accessdate=2007-09-23 |format=pdf}} The elevated roadways and the ring roads gave Birmingham the tag; "Britain's motor city".''[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2701829.stm Tackling congestion in Birmingham]'' - BBC News, 13 February 2003 One commentator described Manzoni's vision of Birmingham as a "''Godless, concrete urban hell''",{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2008/jun/29/architecture.regeneration|title=Article reviewing the Architectural regeneration of Birmingham City Centre|publisher= Guardian|accessdate=25 January 2010 | location=London | first=Stephen | last=Bayley | date=2008-06-29}} another a "''brutalist, concrete-dominated slave to the motor car''"".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/heartofenterprise/future|title=Article describing Birmingham's Big City Plan|publisher= Guardian|accessdate=25 January 2010 | location=London | date=2008-12-02 | first=Ross | last=Reyburn}} In the mid-1980s, [[Birmingham City Council]] decided that they needed to change the image Birmingham had to the public, and improve the [[World's most livable cities|livability]] of the city.{{cite book|author=Michael J. Thomas|author2=Peter Brand|title=Urban Environmentalism: Global Change and the Mediation of Local Conflict|year=2005|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0-415-30480-6}} The first main aim was to target the areas in the city centre that had not been developed following World War II, such as the canals. The council worked closely with Argent, a developer, who redeveloped the area around the canals into a mixed use scheme [[Brindleyplace]], which began in 1994 and was completed in early 2009. This development followed the construction of the [[National Indoor Arena]] and the [[International Convention Centre, Birmingham|International Convention Centre]], which were both completed in 1991.[http://brindleyplace.com/media-office/history Brindleyplace: History] Another major part of the plan was to redevelop the skyline of the city. The skyline mainly consisted of postwar office buildings and through the creation of the "High Places" document, the council aimed to encourage highrise development in the city once more. In 2007, a report was commissioned by the Leader of the Council, Councillor [[Mike Whitby]]. The result was ''The Birmingham City Centre Masterplan: The Visioning Study'' by [[Professor Michael Parkinson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ljmu.ac.uk/EIUA/EIUA_Docs/Birmingham_report_2.pdf|title=The Birmingham City Centre Masterplan: The Visioning Study|publisher=Birmingham City Council|accessdate=25 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229232654/http://www.ljmu.ac.uk/EIUA/EIUA_Docs/Birmingham_report_2.pdf|archivedate=29 February 2012|df=}} The Big City Plan was launched in February 2008. Between December 2008 and February 2009 there was an extensive public consultation stage, engaging with citizens in a variety of ways: a website, newspaper supplements, leaflets, posters, a conference, and even an exhibition on a bus that toured inner-city residential districts.{{cite web|url=http://www.bdonline.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=3145405#ixzz0dltKlzQO|title=Article describing Birmingham's Big City Plan|publisher=Birmingham Post|accessdate=26 January 2010}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Districts== Following the removal of the [[Birmingham Inner Ring Road|Inner Ring Road]], which acted as a 'concrete collar' preventing expansion, the city centre is newly defined as being the area within the [[A4540 road|Middle Ring Road]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ljmu.ac.uk/EIUA/EIUA_Docs/Birmingham_report_2.pdf |title=Birmingham Unitary Development Plan Chapter 15 - City Centre |publisher=Birmingham City Council |accessdate=2008-01-11 |format=pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229232654/http://www.ljmu.ac.uk/EIUA/EIUA_Docs/Birmingham_report_2.pdf |archivedate=2012-02-29 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/eastside |title=Eastside |publisher=Birmingham City Council |accessdate=2008-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905185859/http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/eastside |archivedate=2008-09-05 |df= }} The Big City Plan divided the now much bigger city centre into seven districts, each with its own distinct character.{{cite web|url=http://bigcityplan.birmingham.gov.uk/areas.php |title=Designated Areas of the City Centre |publisher=Big City Plan |accessdate=26 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100124044815/http://bigcityplan.birmingham.gov.uk/areas.php |archivedate=24 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} *[[City Centre Core]] *[[Eastside, Birmingham|Eastside]] *[[Digbeth]] *[[Southside, Birmingham|Southside and Highgate]] *[[Westside, Birmingham|Westside and Ladywood]] *[[Jewellery Quarter]] *[[Gun Quarter]] ==City Centre Core== ===Bull Ring=== {{main|Bull Ring, Birmingham}} [[File:Old Bullring.jpg|thumb|The old Bull Ring Centre, added to the "concrete jungle" image of Birmingham.]] A large part of the scheme was the redevelopment of the Bull Ring, which has been an important feature of Birmingham since the [[Middle Ages]], when its market was first held. It has been developed into a [[Shopping mall|shopping centre]] twice, first in 1964, but its Brutalist architecture became much disliked by the public and the building was seen as a major part of Birmingham's "concrete jungle" image.''[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/magazine/3082216.stm New adventures in concrete]'' - BBC Magazine, 5 September 2003 Realising the need for major changes to the city centre, an alliance of investment and development companies was formed called the [[Birmingham Alliance]] who put the finance together to design and construct the new £500 million Bull Ring shopping centre, which was completed in 2003.{{cite book|author=Kennedy|title=Remaking Birmingham: The Visual Culture of Urban Regeneration|pages=17–18|year=2004|publisher=Routledge Ltd.|isbn=0-415-28839-8}}[http://www.wspgroup.com/en/Sectors/All/Property/Birmingham-Bullring---UK/ WSP Group: Birmingham Bullring UK] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620114822/http://www.wspgroup.com/en/Sectors/All/Property/Birmingham-Bullring---UK/ |date=June 20, 2007 }}''[http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/post/news/tm_method=full%26objectid=14600178%26siteid=50002-name page.html UK's busiest shopping centre]'' - icBirmingham, September 3, 2004 (Accessed March 17, 2007) It is amongst the busiest shopping centres in the [[United Kingdom]] with 36.5 million visitors in 2004. It houses one of only four [[Selfridges]] department stores and the largest [[Debenhams]] outside [[London]].The area is said to bring in around £1 billion per year, and has a footfall of around 36.9 million a year. [[File:Rotunda, Birmingham during refurb.jpg|thumb|left|The Rotunda in 2007 during the refurbishment. The majority of the windows and cladding were installed.]] ===The Rotunda=== {{main|Rotunda (Birmingham)}} The Rotunda was refurbished by [[Urban Splash]] into residential apartments from an office building.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/birmingham/content/articles/2005/10/15/rotunda_skyline_for_sale_feature.shtml Skyline for Sale] - BBC Birmingham The building was stripped to the core and floorplates''[http://www.locatebirmingham.com/news_and_media/news/2006/8/9 Birmingham's Rotunda Development Naked at 40] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215222845/http://www.locatebirmingham.com/news_and_media/news/2006/8/9 |date=December 15, 2007 }}'' - Locate Birmingham, August 9, 2006 before new full-height windows and cladding were added, plus two LED boards to the top of the building.''[http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/birminghampost/news/tm_headline=rotunda-keeps-an-eye-on-the-city&method=full&objectid=19187468&siteid=50002-name_page.html Rotunda keeps an eye on the city]'' - Birmingham Post, May 24, 2007 ===New Street Station=== {{Main|Gateway Plus}} Designs were shown to the public in mid-February 2006 for a new Birmingham New Street station in a project known as [[Gateway Plus]].[http://www.renewstreet.co.uk/default.asp Re-New Street: Change at New Street] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051218030002/http://www.renewstreet.co.uk/default.asp |date=December 18, 2005 }} The plans featured a foyer of open space with a multi-storey entrance. The roof was composed completely of glass to allow natural light to enter the entrance hall. The façade will have rounded edges and the [[Grand Central, Birmingham|Pallasades Shopping Centre]] above the station will remain. A planning application for outline planning permission was submitted to the council in August 2006 which shows a glass façade with rounded edges. The entrance on Station Street originally included two curved 130 metre tall towers on the site of Stephenson Tower. Due to the economic slowdown, the office space is not needed, and the "twin towers" plan has been shelved until the market picks up.http://www.birminghammail.net/news/top-stories/2009/08/24/twin-towers-plan-for-new-street-station-shelved-due-to-economic-downturn-97319-24517039/ Twin towers plan for New Street station shelved
Work began on the new station in September 2009. The building work will be done in phases in an attempt to minimise disruption to passengers and shoppers. Building work is expected to last until at least 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.net/news/localtravel/localtravelnews/2009/08/19/work-set-to-start-on-new-street-station-97319-24479987|title=Work set to start on New Street Station}}http://www.birminghammail.net/news/top-stories/2009/08/11/new-street-revamp-work-close-to-starting-97319-24370064/ Revamp work close to starting ===Snowhill=== {{main|Snowhill}} [[File:Snowhill Phase 2 in August 2008.JPG|thumb|One Snowhill.]] The Snowhill scheme adjacent to [[Birmingham Snow Hill railway station|Snow Hill station]] is a large mixed-use development. Developed by Ballymore, it will feature two office blocks, a hotel tower and a 137-metre residential tower. One Snowhill was the first building in the development. The accountancy firm [[KPMG]] has {{convert|118400|sqft|m2|0}} of office space in the building on a 20-year lease{{cite web |url=http://www.commercialpropertynews.com/cpn/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003593645 |title=Ballymore Gains Approval for Birmingham Project |publisher=''Commercial Property News'' |author=Marshall Taylor |date=2007-06-04 |accessdate=2007-12-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080614001313/http://www.commercialpropertynews.com/cpn/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003593645 |archivedate=2008-06-14 |df= }} on floors 7 to 11.{{cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/en/bu/nc/ne/?id=101983 |title=Ballymore ploughs through at Snowhill |publisher=''Emporis'' |author=Neil Nickolds |date=2008-02-03 |accessdate=2008-03-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315155313/http://www.emporis.com/en/bu/nc/ne/?id=101983 |archivedate=2008-03-15 |df= }} Following this, [[Barclays]] agreed to move its Midlands headquarters to One Snowhill. They are to take up {{convert|98000|sqft|m2|0}} of space on floors three to six on a 15-year lease with its own dedicated reception and meeting suite. 1,000 sales and operations staff will move into the office building.{{cite web |url=http://www.birminghampost.net/birmingham-business/birmingham-business-news/other-uk-business/2008/07/21/barclays-to-move-midland-hq-to-snowhill-complex-65233-21377104/ |title=Barclays to move Midland HQ to Snowhill complex |publisher=''[[Birmingham Post]]'' |author=Steve Pain |date=2008-07-21 |accessdate=2008-07-29 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725023906/http://www.birminghampost.net/birmingham-business/birmingham-business-news/other-uk-business/2008/07/21/barclays-to-move-midland-hq-to-snowhill-complex-65233-21377104/ |archivedate=25 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The pre-let to Barclays is believed to be the reason why they were comfortable to refinance the loan for the construction of the building.{{cite news|url=http://www.propertyweek.com/story.asp?storycode=3141468 |title=Barclays to refinance Snowhill |date=2009-05-09 |publisher=Property Week |accessdate=2009-08-31}} Snowhill One was completed in 2009. Construction of Two Snowhill was suspended in 2009, with the basement level and slip form cores having been completed. The project restarted in 2011 with the shell and core works being completed in early 2013. Office floors 1 to 6 have been completed to 'Cat A' standard and are now available for lease. Floors 7 to 14 are currently being fitted out for legal firm, [[Wragge & Co]] who have signed up for {{convert|250000|sqft|m2}} of space, a new record for the Birmingham office market.{{cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=5158 |title=Ballymore Gains Approval for Birmingham Project |publisher=Skyscraper News'' |accessdate=2010-02-01| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100212053327/http://skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=5158| archivedate= 12 February 2010 | deadurl= no}} In a major move which will give Birmingham its first five-star hotel, Ballymore confirmed that US operator [[Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide|Starwood Hotels & Resorts]] has entered into an agreement to open a new 198 bedroom [[Westin Hotels|Westin Hotel & Spa]].{{cite news|url= http://www.europe-re.com/system/main.php?pageid=2616&articleid=10463|title=Starwood Hotels announce Birmingham's first 5-star hotel|date=2008-01-25 |publisher=Europe Real Estate|accessdate=2010-02-01}} However, building has stopped due to the financial backer pulling out. As part of the development, St Chads Circus was levelled with the underpasses filled in.[http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/GenerateContent?CONTENT_ITEM_ID=85163&CONTENT_ITEM_TYPE=0&EXPAND=10935&MENU_ID=14463 St Chad's Intersection / Snow Hill Queensway roadworks] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070517194208/http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/GenerateContent?CONTENT_ITEM_ID=85163&CONTENT_ITEM_TYPE=0&EXPAND=10935&MENU_ID=14463 |date=May 17, 2007 }} A new square created adjacent to [[Cathedral of Saint Chad, Birmingham|Saint Chad's Cathedral]], with the aim of attracting more pedestrians to the area. ===Midland Metro=== {{main|Midland Metro}} The coalition government has given funding approval for the extension of the Midland Metro from [[Birmingham Snow Hill railway station|Birmingham Snow Hill station]], passing through the shopping district to Birmingham New Street station. The £127 million state-of-the-art, electrically powered light rail system will also provide quick and easy access to Birmingham's business district and the Jewellery Quarter. Track laying was due to start in 2013 with a completion date of 2015 however following a number of delays the extension was finally opened on 30 May 2016. The extension is forecast to boost the regional economy by £50 million a year and create up to 1,300 sustainable new jobs.{{cite web |url=http://www.centro.org.uk/metro/metroservices.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101028012730/http://www.centro.org.uk/metro/metroservices.aspx |archivedate=2010-10-28 |df= }} Centro Website{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghampost.net/news/west-midlands-transport-news/2010/10/21/relief-for-birmingham-as-midland-metro-is-spare-the-axe-65233-27521895|title=Relief for Birmingham as Midland Metro is spare the axe|author=Edward Chadwick}} This extension has now been carried out and there are other extensions planned for the future by TfWM. ==Westside and Ladywood== {{Main|Westside, Birmingham}} ===The Library of Birmingham=== The [[Library of Birmingham]] is a new library at Centenary Square beside the [[Birmingham Rep]] and [[Baskerville House]], replacing [[Birmingham Central Library]] in 2013. It is part of a pedestrian axis extending from [[Centenary Square]] to the [[Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery]]. It is estimated the new library cost £193 million{{cite web|url=http://www.capitasymonds.co.uk/projects/all_projects/library_of_birmingham.aspx|publisher=Capita Symonds|title=Library of Birmingham|accessdate=2010-02-17| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100305162403/http://www.capitasymonds.co.uk/projects/all_projects/library_of_birmingham.aspx| archivedate= 5 March 2010 | deadurl= no}} and is seen by [[Birmingham City Council]] as a flagship project for the Redevelopment of Birmingham and is set to become the largest public library in Britain.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/apr/03/libraries-architecture-birmingham|title=Library of Birmingham plans unveiled as recession opens a new chapter for civic buildings|author=Robert Booth | location=London|work=The Guardian|date=2009-04-03}}[[File:Libraryofbirmingham.jpg|thumb|The Library of Birmingham at [[Centenary Square]] with [[Birmingham Rep]] in foreground.]] ===The Cube=== [[The Cube (building)|The Cube]] is a 23 [[storey]] cuboid tower completed in 2010, in Birmingham, England. Designed by [[Ken Shuttleworth (architect)|Ken Shuttleworth]] of [[Make Architects]], the [[Mixed-use development|mixed use development]] contains 135 flats, 111,500 ft² (10,360 m²) of offices, shops, a hotel and a 'skyline' restaurant. It is the final phase of [[The Mailbox]] development. It has already been dubbed 'Tetris Tower' by some [[Brummies]] due to the exterior resembling the shapes on the game [[Tetris]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thecubeiscoming.com/Official |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110181635/http://www.thecubeiscoming.com/Official |archivedate=2016-01-10 |df= }} Cube Building Website The [[Highways Agency]] have relocated their offices to The Cube from [[Five Ways, Birmingham|Five Ways]].[http://www.highways.gov.uk/news/PressStatements.aspx?PressStatementID=39&JScript=1 Highways Agency Press Statement] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718005755/http://www.highways.gov.uk/news/PressStatements.aspx?PressStatementID=39&JScript=1 |date=July 18, 2012 }} ===Arena Central=== The Arena Central project includes offices, apartments, leisure facilities, bars and restaurants on Broad Street on the site of the former ATV / Central Television Studios which had closed in 1997. Construction has been delayed due to the property market slump. The [[V Building]] is a proposed 51 storey landmark residential skyscraper. It will be located next to [[Alpha Tower]], one of the tallest buildings in Birmingham, on what is currently a multi-level underground car park. The total cost of the entire scheme is expected to be £400 million, and the tower, £150 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.arena-central.com/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100315155259/http://www.arena-central.com/index.html |archivedate=2010-03-15 |df= }} Official Arena Central website Planning permission was granted in 2005, however developers Miller Developments and Bridgehouse Capital have been granted a five-year extension on planning permission for the V Building meaning it must be built by 2015. It is believed the larger Arena Central site may not be completed until 2030.http://www.birminghampost.net/news/west-midlands-news/2009/11/06/birmingham-won-t-wait-ten-years-for-start-on-arena-central-v-building-65233-25103305/Birmingham Post article about extension of planning on the V Building ===Regal Tower=== [[Regal Tower]] is a proposed [[skyscraper]] to be constructed on the corner of [[Broad Street, Birmingham|Broad Street]] and Sheepcote Street in Birmingham, [[England]].{{cite web|url=http://eplanning.birmingham.gov.uk/Northgate/PlanningExplorer/Generic/StdDetails.aspx?PT=Planning%20Applications%20On-Line&TYPE=PL/PlanningPK.xml&PARAM0=365388&XSLT=/Northgate/PlanningExplorer/SiteFiles/Skins/Birmingham/xslt/PL/PLDetails.xslt&FT=Planning%20Application%20Details&PUBLIC=Y&XMLSIDE=/Northgate/PlanningExplorer/SiteFiles/Skins/Birmingham/Menus/PL.xml&DAURI=PLANNING |title=Details Page for Planning Application - 2009/04215/PA |year=2009 |publisher=Birmingham City Council |accessdate=2009-09-28}} The proposal consists of a 56-storey tower, measuring {{convert|200.5|m|ft|0}} tall, housing retail units, a luxury hotel, residential apartments and car parking. Provision has been made for 256 serviced apartments, although these could become additional hotel space. It is estimated it will cost £125million to construct, and when completed, it will become the tallest building in the city at 200m. ===Park Central=== [[Lee Bank]] was a large inner-city council estate, which was one of five areas designated as a redevelopment area following World War 2.[http://www.gees.bham.ac.uk/research/cpp/membersfiles/phil/leebankabstract.pdf Tower Block Modernism vs. Urban Morphology: An analysis of Lee Bank, Birmingham] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227084303/http://www.gees.bham.ac.uk/research/cpp/membersfiles/phil/leebankabstract.pdf |date=February 27, 2008 }} Originally slum housing, it was cleared by the council who constructed numerous tower blocks and low rise maisonettes. Lee Bank began to deteriorate following poor construction which led to inadequate maintenance.[http://www.bcen.net/uploads/briefings/Optima_28_SEPT05.pdf Birmingham Community Empowerment Network: BRIEFING 28 SEPT 05] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928010228/http://www.bcen.net/uploads/briefings/Optima_28_SEPT05.pdf |date=2007-09-28 }} The estate was purchased by [[Optima Housing]] who aimed to redevelop the site. The development, known as [[Park Central]], is phase one of a larger area Optima are developing called [[Attwood Green]]. Phase one is being built by [[Crest Nicholson]] and has resulted in the demolition of all the [[tower block]]s on the former Lee Bank estate.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070930225817/http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/GenerateContent?CONTENT_ITEM_ID=87123&CONTENT_ITEM_TYPE=0&MENU_ID=1452 Birmingham.gov.uk: Demolition of Haddon Tower] Park Central is one of Europe's largest urban renaissance projects.[http://www.optima.org.uk/history.ph Optima Housing: History] ===Paradise, Birmingham=== {{Main|Paradise, Birmingham}} Paradise, Birmingham, previously known as Paradise Circus, is a large site in the city centre in which the council has investigated options for redeveloping the site following the imminent demolition of [[Birmingham Central Library]]. At present, it is home to the Central Library, [[Birmingham Conservatoire]] (including the [[Adrian Boult Hall]]), Birmingham Library Theatre and [[Paradise Forum]]. It was designed by [[John Madin]] and the [[Brutalist]] architecture of the conglomerate of buildings is seen by many as contributing to Birmingham's [[wiktionary:Concrete jungle|concrete jungle]] image.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/birmingham/your_birmingham/restoration/trash_or_treasure.shtml|title=Trash or Treasure?}} [http://www.paradisecircus.co.uk The Paradise, Birmingham redevelopment] has been an important part of the redevelopment of the city centre, and plans from the 1990s suggested the construction of [[skyscraper]]s.[http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=569 Skyscrapernews.com: Paradise Circus Redevelopment Tower] The site was also identified as an appropriate location for a tall building under the "High Places" document.[http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/cs/Satellite?blobcol=urldata&blobheader=application%2Fpdf&blobheadername1=Content-Disposition&blobkey=id&blobtable=MungoBlobs&blobwhere=1223493000666&ssbinary=true&blobheadervalue1=attachment%3B+filename%3D398540High_Places.pdf Birmingham High Places Document] The development is estimated to cost £1 billion, and the council has joined with several major developers involved in projects across the city to establish plans for the site.''[http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/0100news/post/tm_headline=-pound-1bn-paradise-circus-makeover-revealed&method=full&objectid=15468303&siteid=50002-name_page.html £1bn Paradise Circus makeover revealed]'' - Birmingham Post, May 2, 2005 However, a report into the financial feasibility of redeveloping the site warned the project was financially flawed and unlikely to succeed.''[http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/0100news/0100localnews/tm_objectid=15161768&method=full&siteid=50002&headline=paradise-circus-secrets-revealed-name_page.html Paradise Circus secrets revealed]'' - icBirmingham, Feb 7 2005 As of May 2007, Argent are investing £2 million to improve the interior of Paradise Forum.''[http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/birminghampost/news/tm_method=full%26objectid=17280362%26siteid=50002-name_page.html Touches of Paradise come to Forum at last]'' - Birmingham Post, Jun 23 2006 In July 2012, Argent submitted an outline planning application to develop up to 10 new buildings, which include a new upgraded Copthorne and a concert hall for [[Birmingham City University]]’s school of music. Chamberlain Square and Centenary Square will be linked through news public squares whilst pedestrians will be encouraged around the site with new leisure, cultural and civic amenities. Granted planning permission be approved at the end of 2012, construction will begin in 2014 for an estimated completion date of 2017.''[http://www.birminghampost.co.uk/news/local-news/plans-lodged-development-around-birminghams-3911284 Plans lodged for development around Birmingham's Paradise Circus]'' - Birmingham Post, Jul 26 2012''[http://www.birminghampost.co.uk/news/local-news/paradise-circus-development-to-return-3909676 Paradise Circus development 'to return Birmingham to pedestrians']'' - Birmingham Post, Jul 26 2012 ==Eastside== {{Main|Eastside, Birmingham}} [[File:Matthew Boulton College.jpg|left|thumb|[[Birmingham Metropolitan College]] Matthew Boulton campus after completion in 2005.]] Eastside is a new area of Birmingham city centre made possible by the demolition of a large elevated road junction called [[Masshouse Circus]] and the [[A4400 road|Inner Ring Road]]. This was known as the "concrete collar". The council drew up plans to develop the former industrial area into a vibrant area. They also aimed to create a technology quarter, due to the proximity to [[Aston Science Park]], and to create an education quarter, due to the proximity of [[Aston University]]. The area has been sold to various developers who are being encouraged to build large mixed use schemes. The first building to be completed in Eastside was [[Millennium Point (Birmingham)|Millennium Point]] in the education quarter. This has since been followed by the completion of the [[New Technology Institute]] and the new [[Birmingham Metropolitan College]] Matthew Boulton campus. ===Eastside City Park=== [[Eastside City Park]] is a proposed [[urban park]] in Birmingham, [[United Kingdom]], projected to cover at least {{convert|8|acre|m2}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/GenerateContent?CONTENT_ITEM_ID=66143&CONTENT_ITEM_TYPE=0&MENU_ID=0|title=Eastside City Park - news and information|accessdate=2008-11-09|publisher=Birmingham City Council|year=2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080609160442/http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/GenerateContent?CONTENT_ITEM_ID=66143&CONTENT_ITEM_TYPE=0&MENU_ID=0 |archivedate = 2008-06-09}} including the existing Park Street Gardens. The scheme is part of the [[Eastside, Birmingham|Eastside regeneration programme]], and is expected to be completed in 2013. It is the first city centre park created in Birmingham for 125 years and will double the amount of open space in the city centre. ===City Park Gate=== The City Park Gate scheme located immediately adjacent to [[Birmingham Moor Street railway station|Moor Street station]] will deliver over {{convert|450000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of Grade A offices, a 200-room hotel, 250 residential apartments, and {{convert|15000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of retail. The scheme will also include a major new public square. An outline planning application for the development, designed by [[Make Architects]], received consent on 10 May 2007.''[http://www.worldarchitecturenews.com/index.php?fuseaction=wanappln.projectview&upload_id=1069 Make Architects get green light for City Park Gate project]'' - World Architecture News (Monday 14 May 2007) Construction is expected to begin in early 2008. ===Masshouse=== {{main|Masshouse}} [[File:Masshouse block M -Birmingham -UK.jpg|thumb|Masshouse Block I after it had been topped out.]] Masshouse is a development with the construction of 13 new highrise blocks intended for public services, commerce and residential purposes. When completed, the blocks will have a prominent position on the Eastside skyline. Also planned for location at Masshouse was [[Birmingham Magistrates' Court (building)|Birmingham Magistrates' Court]], which was scheduled to begin building in March 2010 to be completed in early 2013, but has since been cancelled by the Conservative-LibDem Coalition government. In mid-2010, city planners approved proposals for a nine-storey, 174 bed hotel beside the existing Masshouse building. The Hotel La Tour group plans to open the four star in February 2012, creating 100 full and part-time jobs in the area. The development will include a restaurant, bar, gym and conference facilities. ===Martineau Galleries=== [[Martineau Galleries]] is a proposed mixed-use development which will connect the Eastside to the city centre core and is also located on the High Street, a major retail area. The design contains residential and office blocks as well as an open area surrounded by shops. There are also five rooftop gardens. There is also a block with two towers protruding one of which is estimated to be 110 metres in height with 29 floors and a sloped roof with two rooftop gardens either side of these. The other is shorter however also has the sloped roof. It is proposed that there are eight buildings in total on site. ===High Speed 2=== Eastside is the planned location for the city centre terminus station for ''[[High Speed 2]] (HS2)'' phase one at [[Curzon Street railway station]]. It is expected that once HS2 is complete journey times from London into Birmingham City Centre will be reduced to 45 minutes with the potential to bring £1.4 billion of economic value ([[Gross value added|GVA]]) into the region.{{dubious|date=April 2012}} Birmingham City Council's Gross value added, sets out how investment in the Curzon area will enable the city to benefit from the improved connectivity with London (phase one 2026) and northern cities in phase two.{{cite report | date = June 2016 | title = Curzon Investment plan | url = https://www.birmingham.gov.uk/downloads/file/5174/curzon_investment_plan | publisher = www.birmingham.gov.uk | format = PDF | pages = 4, 20 | access-date = 17 February 2018 }} ==Digbeth== ===Beorma Quarter=== [[File:Beormatower.jpg|thumb|How the controversial Beorma Tower will look from the Bullring.]] The [[Beorma]] Quarter is planned for construction from 2010 onwards, as a multimillion-pound 27-storey city-within-a-city development on a site at the end of [[Digbeth]] High Street, directly opposite Birmingham's already iconic [[Selfridges]] building (it will occupy the site of the city's last seven [[burgage]] plots [http://www.e-architect.co.uk/birmingham/beorma_quarter_digbeth.htm e-architect]). Complete with state-of-the-art environmental and energy systems, the final development is likely to consist of a [[Marriott Hotel]], apartments, green spaces, a niche shopping centre, a public space intended to house Birmingham's historic [[John F. Kennedy]] memorial and two refurbished cold storage buildings which will be redeveloped as creative industries business incubation and innovation hubs.{{Cite web |url=http://www.beormaquarter.com/city.html |title=Beorma Quarter |access-date=2010-10-30 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130117205603/http://www.beormaquarter.com/city.html |archive-date=2013-01-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Planning permission was granted for the Beorma Quarter in August 2009, despite the fact that the project contravenes at least two of the City Council’s own planning policies. It is outside the city's designated tall building area and is also in the middle of a conservation area. The tower was described as "abominable" and "like a punch in the face by an architectural fist" by the city’s Conservative and Heritage Panel. Preliminary work on the construction of the Beorma Quarter began in December 2010. Work started with stripping out the listed Cold Store building opposite St. Martin's Church. The conversion of the historic, {{convert|35,000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} building will create an innovation centre for businesses. By February 2011, a question mark remained over the development of the site's 27-storey tower block, as construction will only commence once occupiers are found.{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.net/news/top-stories/2009/02/10/birmingham-beorma-quarter-tower-block-plan-panned-97319-22893205|title=Birmingham Beorma Quarter tower block plan panned}} ===Birmingham Coach Station=== Digbeth Coach Station underwent a £15 million redevelopment in 2009 and was renamed [[Birmingham coach station]]. It is a major coach interchange offering services to destinations throughout [[Great Britain]] and also to [[Belfast]], [[Dublin]] and [[Poland]]. [[National Express Coaches|National Express]], the largest scheduled coach service provider in [[Europe]], has its national headquarters on the site.{{cite web|url=http://www.lsh.co.uk/pages/news_detail.asp?id=1251|title=LSH plays integral role in £15m redevelopment of Birmingham Coach Station|publisher=LSH|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009121948/http://www.lsh.co.uk/pages/news_detail.asp?id=1251|archivedate=2011-10-09|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/mail/news/tm_objectid=17241328%26method=full%26siteid=50002-name_page.html|title=Green light for coach station rebuild|accessdate=2006-06-16 |publisher=Birmingham Mail|year=2006}} ===Other developments=== The completion of [[South Birmingham College|South Birmingham College: Digbeth]] and the renovation of the [[Custard Factory]] also attracted interest to the area economically with the opening of a [[Cadillac]] [[automobile]] showroom in the area in early 2006, despite the council naming the area as a media quarter. The Custard Factory is again set for an expansion with the refurbishment of the adjacent Devonshire House being approved by Birmingham City Council in August 2007. Scaffolding has been erected around the structure. A further planning application has been submitted for the installation of artwork on one of the railway arches making up the Digbeth Viaduct. Opposite the Custard Factory is a five-storey office development named Rhubarb designed by Bryant Priest Newman Architects which was completed in February 2010. [[Deritend]] is also expected to witness a vast amount of redevelopment. A large number of low-rise residential schemes have been proposed with several beginning construction in 2005 and 2006. Deritend Bridge (so called because of its location near a bridge which crossed the [[River Rea]] called Deritend Bridge) was a large residential development planned for the area. It received outline planning consent however the land was then sold by the developers to another company. The site is now set to be developed into a large mixed-use scheme named Connaught Square by the Naus Group.{{cite web|url=http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/birminghampost/news/tm_method=full%26objectid=19634466%26siteid=50002-name_page.html|title=£150m makeover for Irish quarter unveiled|date=2007-08-15|publisher=The Birmingham Post|accessdate=2007-09-20}} The development in Deritend extends towards the [[Bordesley, West Midlands|Bordesley]] area which borders Eastside. An area between Fazeley Street and the [[Grand Union Canal]] in Digbeth, named [[Warwick Bar]], has become the focus of redevelopment itself with the construction of new modern buildings and a restoration project of an old Victorian storage facility. Proposals are also being planned for the area including a little-known project known as "''The Needle''". Its location is not known according to a developments document issued however it would most likely be at Warwick Bar. ==Southside and Highgate== ===Southside BID=== The Southside Business Improvement District (BID) is a plan for the local business community to come together to develop projects and services that will benefit the environment of Southside. === Gay Village === At the end of May 2009, the City Council approved plans for a £530,000 environmental improvement scheme at the heart of the city’s Gay Village area. The proposals include extending the avenue of street trees to the full length of [[Hurst Street]] and parts of Kent Street; widening pavements to create space for café bars to provide outdoor seating and brighter street lighting with decorative lanterns.http://bigcityplan.birmingham.gov.uk/documents/BCP_news_autumn2009.pdf{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=Cyberbot II |fix-attempted=yes }} This plan may now be funded by Southside BID. == Jewellery Quarter == ===Golden Square=== In August 2010, planning permission was granted for a new £1.5 million square at the heart of Birmingham’s historic [[Jewellery Quarter]]. Created by Birmingham-based architects, Capita Lovejoy, the ‘Golden Square’ will provide a focal point for visitors and shoppers within the Quarter. Construction is due to start in Autumn 2011, with completion in Spring 2012.{{cite web |url=http://goldensquarebirmingham.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101115131222/http://goldensquarebirmingham.com/ |archivedate=2010-11-15 |df= }} Golden Square Website === Newhall Square === [[Newhall Square, Birmingham|Newhall Square]] is a vibrant new mixed use development on the site of the former [[Museum of Science and Industry, Birmingham|Museum of Science and Industry]] on Newhall Street. It will include a range of new and restored listed buildings set around a major new square fronting the canal. ==High rise development== [[File:Orion and Holloway Buildings Birmingham -UK.JPG|thumb|upright|Holloway Circus Tower (right) and the Orion Building (left) from Centenary Square.]] To improve the skyline of Birmingham, the "High Places" document was produced by the council to outline appropriate places for highrise buildings and to explain what the council expects from their design. Birmingham city centre is located on a sandstone ridge and is about 100 metres above sea level meaning that towers no taller than 40 storeys are advised due to [[Civil Aviation Authority of the United Kingdom|CAA]] height restrictions. Several towers have been proposed for Birmingham since. [[Beetham Tower, Birmingham|Beetham Tower]] was originally proposed at 191 metres, however, the height restrictions meant the height was cut down to 122 metres.[http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=153 Skyscrapernews.com: Holloway Circus Tower] It has since been completed. [[V Building]], first known as Arena Central Tower, was first proposed at 245 metres[http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=117 Skyscrapernews.com: Arena Central Tower] but was also shortened to 175 metres. The building was redesigned by [[Eric Kuhne and Associates|Eric Kuhne]]''[http://www.building.co.uk/story.asp?sectioncode=736&storycode=3083190&c=3&encCode=00000000012b6a3f Kuhne's Arena Central tower unveiled at MIPIM]'' - Building, March 15, 2007 and is proposed at 152 metres.[http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=5155 Skyscrapernews.com: The V Building] One building, [[Broad Street Tower]], surpasses the height restrictions. It received planning approval in 2006 when [[Birmingham International Airport (United Kingdom)|Birmingham International Airport]] withdrew objections to the tower.''[http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/birminghampost/news/tm_objectid=17840747%26method=full%26siteid=50002%26headline=planners%2dgive%2dgo%2dahead%2dto%2d40%2dstorey%2dbirmingham%2dtower%2d-name_page.html Planners give go-ahead to 40-storey Birmingham tower]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}'' - Birmingham Post (Sep 29 2006) ==Outside of the City Centre== The new [[Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham]] is the city's first superhospital, completed in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.uhb.nhs.uk/blogs/NewHospital/2009/03/birminghams-new-hospital-named.html|title=Birmingham's new hospital named|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100311010340/http://www.uhb.nhs.uk/blogs/NewHospital/2009/03/birminghams-new-hospital-named.html|archivedate=2010-03-11|df=}} The completion cost was £545 million. The new hospital replaces [[Selly Oak Hospital]] and the old [[Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham (1933–2010)]]. The [[City of Birmingham Stadium]] was a proposed multi-purpose stadium in the [[Saltley]] area of Birmingham for [[Birmingham City F.C.]], to replace the current [[St Andrews (stadium)|St Andrews Stadium]] in [[Bordesley Green]]. The original proposal was the centrepiece of a larger scheme to create a £300 million sports village on a {{convert|60|acre|m2|adj=on}} site, however, plans for the sports village fell through when plans for a proposed supercasino for the site also fell through. The stadium plans will rejuvenate a contaminated site currently used by [[Birmingham Wheels]].''[http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/mail/news/tm_method=full%26objectid=19125215%26siteid=50002-name_page.html New super stadium a step closer]'' - Birmingham Mail, May 18, 2007 (Accessed May 29, 2007) Urban Splash also developed [[Fort Dunlop]], a former factory building next to the [[M6 motorway]], which opened in December 2006.[http://www.fortdunlop.com/FortDunlop.html Fort Dunlop website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070518131113/http://www.fortdunlop.com/FortDunlop.html |date=May 18, 2007 }} Bournville College has relocated to Longbridge on the former site of the MG Rover works. ==See also== * [[List of tallest buildings and structures in Birmingham]] * [[Architecture of Birmingham]] * [[Midlands Engine]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{City of Birmingham}} {{Economy of the United Kingdom}} [[Category:Economy of Birmingham, West Midlands]] [[Category:Local government in Birmingham, West Midlands]] [[Category:City plans]] [[Category:Town and country planning in England]]

page.title: Bishop White Gallery of Chinese Temple Art

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
The '''Bishop White Gallery of Chinese Temple Art''' <ref>http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/bishop-white-gallery-chinese-temple-art</ref> is one of four galleries in the [[Royal Ontario Museum]] (ROM) that are dedicated to Chinese art and archaeology. It contains one of the most important collections of Chinese temple art in the world,<ref>http://romlx6.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/bishop.php{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> including three [[Yuan Dynasty]] (1271 – 1368 AD) temple wall paintings from [[Shanxi Province]] that adorn the three walls of the Gallery, and several wooden sculptures depicting bodhisattvas from the 12th to the 15th centuries. These are some of the earliest acquisitions and most [[Royal Ontario Museum Iconic Objects|iconic objects in the ROM]].[[File:Bishop White Gallery, Royal Ontario Museum.jpg|thumb|Temple statues and mural in the Gallery]]
==Name of the Gallery==
The Gallery is named in honour of [[William White (Bishop of Honan)|Bishop William Charles White]] (1873-1960), an [[Anglican]] missionary, educated at Wycliffe College in the [[University of Toronto]], who became Bishop of [[Henan province|Honan Province]], China (1909-1934). Bishop White was chiefly responsible for building and interpreting the ROM's Chinese collection in the early days and, in particular, for the acquisition of the Buddhist wall painting on the north wall of this Gallery and the H.H. Mu <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://guides.library.utoronto.ca/content.php?pid=457463&sid=3847487# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-01-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140117032139/http://guides.library.utoronto.ca/content.php?pid=457463&sid=3847487# |archive-date=2014-01-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Far Eastern Library . [[File:Bishop White on wheelbarrow.jpg|right|thumb|Bishop White in China]] He was also the first curator of the East Asian galleries (1934-1948) and founder of the School of Chinese Studies (later the East Asian Studies Department) at the University of Toronto in 1934. The Bishop White Committee in the Royal Ontario Museum was founded shortly after his death to promote the collections of the East Asian Galleries.<ref>Walmsley L, Bishop in Honan. Toronto: University of Toronto Press (1974)</ref>
==Contents of the Bishop White Gallery==
The collections of this Gallery are mostly [[Buddhist]], including the wall painting on the north wall of the Gallery, The Paradise of Maitreya, and the wooden sculptures, which are mostly of a later provenance; but the other two wall paintings, both entitled Homage to the First Principle, are from the [[Daoist]] tradition.
=== The Paradise of Maitreya (1298 AD)=== [[File:Paradise of Maitreya, Royal Ontario Museum.jpg|thumb|Paradise of Maitreya]] The wall painting depicts Maitreya, the Buddha of the future and successor to the historical Buddha, enthroned in heaven and awaiting his incarnation on earth where he will save the souls of lost humanity. Maitreya himself is the central figure but he is joined by a goodly retinue of greater and lesser bodhisattvas and monks (arhats, or 'luohan' in Chinese). According to the Indian Buddhist tradition, Maitreya will be born in to the Kingdom of Ketumati, whose King and Queen are depicted here, at the far left and right, 'taking the tonsure' (i.e., having their heads shaved) as a sign of their conversion to Buddhism.
The [[Paradise of Maitreya]], which measures approximately 16 (height) x 36 (width) feet, is known to have come from the Monastery of Joyful Conversion (Xinghua Si) in southern [[Shanxi Province]], which has long since been destroyed after falling into ruins.<ref>Tsang, "The Paradise of Maitreya: A Yuan Dynasty Mural from Shanxi Province" in Orientation: The Magazine for Collectors and Connoisseurs of Asian Art. (Spring 2006)</ref> The painting remained in situ and was undisturbed until the 1920s, when social and political unrest in China led to the destruction of many temples in the northern part of the country. To protect the wall paintings from war lords who were looting the northern monasteries, the Buddhist monks resolved to cut the painting in to 63 sections and hid them.<ref>Walmsley L, Bishop in Honan, p. 153. Toronto: University of Toronto Press (1974)</ref> They eventually sold the painting in 1923 to a syndicate of Chinese art dealers from Beijing from whom Bishop White purchased it in 1928 for the Royal Ontario Museum where it was installed in 1933 after being reassembled.<ref name="ROM">Royal Ontario Museum. The Bishop White Gallery: Wall Paintings and Wood Sculptures from Shanxi Province, China. Toronto: Royal Ontario Museum (1990)</ref> It was acquired through the generosity of the Sir Joseph Flavelle Foundation, in memory of Sir [[Joseph Flavelle]], a prominent Toronto businessman and Trustee of the ROM.<ref name="ROM"/>
The Paradise of Maitreya is currently dated as having been composed in 1298 and is one of the best surviving examples of its kind from late Yuan period, but there has been much scholarly debate about the exact date of composition. Bishop White himself contributed a monograph on the subject,<ref name="White">White W., Chinese Temple Frescoes (1940)</ref> arguing for a slightly earlier date, and suggesting that the painting should be attributed to Zhu Haogu, whose name Bishop White procured from the temple records before it was destroyed. This attribution has been accepted by subsequent scholars and has been a useful point of reference for research into the development of a Buddhist-Daoist style of temple art in southern Shanxi Province.<ref>Stenhardt, N. "Zhu Haogu Reconsidered: A New Date for the ROM Painting and the Southern Shanxi Buddhist-Daoist Style," in Artibus Asiae (1987)</ref>
===The Sculptures (12-15th Centuries)===
These Buddhist sculptures are [[bodhisattvas]], enlightened beings who have remained on earth rather than entering paradise in order to help others attain enlightenment. These sculptures also come from Shanxi Province, though not from the same temple as the Paradise of Maitreya, and were intended as icons by which to evoke the presence of the divine, with the wall paintings serving as a background. The most famous of these are a pair of bodhisattvas, [[Guanyin]] and Dashiji, who are almost identical except for some of their accoutrements, like the diadems they wear. Their creation is attested as being in the year 1195 by an inscription set into the lower back of Guanyin, which makes them unique, as only a very few wooden sculptures of this kind dated to the 12th century are known to have survived. Many of the sculptures in the Bishop White Gallery have openings in their backs where devotees would leave offerings (e.g., printed prayers, small images or precious gems and metals) at the time of dedication to ensure their efficacy as objects of prayer.<ref>Royal Ontario Museum, Homage to Heaven, Homage to Earth: Chinese Treasures of the Royal Ontario Museum. P.178. Toronto: Royal Ontario Museum (1992)</ref>
Bishop White surmised that most of the statues in this Gallery were sculpted from a variety of catalpa, either in pieces or from a single block.<ref name="White"/> All of these sculptures were acquired through the efforts of George Crofts, a fur merchant who was also instrumental as an agent in the Chinese art market of the early 20th century, and arrived to the ROM before 1925.<ref>Royal Ontario Museum, Homage to Heaven, Homage to Earth: Chinese Treasures of the Royal Ontario Museum. P.9. Toronto: Royal Ontario Museum (1992)</ref>
===Homage to the First Principle (1271 - 1368 AD)=== [[File:Homage to the Highest Principle (1 of 2), Royal Ontario Museum.jpg|right|thumb|Homage to the Highest Principle]] On the east and west walls of the Bishop White Gallery are a pair of two slightly smaller paintings, [[Homage to the Highest Power|Homage to the Highest Principle]], that depict a procession of Daoist deities and their celestial attendants, sometimes referred to as Chaoyuan tu or the 'Heavenly Court'. These deities, whose court is modeled on the bureaucratic structure of the earthly world, are said to maintain the order of nature and to govern the welfare of human beings. In their original monastic context, these processional paintings would have led up to a great picture at the end of the room, probably depicting the heavenly host.<ref>Currely, C. I Brought the Ages Home. Toronto: Ryerson Press (1990)</ref> In the Bishop White Gallery, the north wall is occupied by the Paradise of Maitreya, a Buddhist painting but with a similar motif and treatment of the subject matter as what would have been seen in the original Daoist temple. By the time that these paintings were being produced in the 13th or 14th century, Buddhism had been assimilated into the Chinese philosophical system, and this syncretism had long since begun to influence iconography.<ref name="ROM"/>
The provenance of these paintings, which both measure approximately 10 (height) x 34 (width) feet, is not known with certainty. It is thought that they came from a Daoist temple in southern [[Shanxi]], whose name and exact location are unknown, but the stylistic similarity between these and other paintings found in another Shanxi Daoist temple, Yongle Gong, suggests that they might have come from the same workshop and be roughly contemporaneous, dating from the early 14th century.<ref>Tsang, K., Gesterkamp, L and Ruitenbeek, K. Beyond Clouds and Waves: Daoist paintings in the Royal Ontario Museum. P. 45-63. Toronto: Royal Ontario Museum (2013)</ref> Since the paintings in Yongle Gong bear the inscription of the master Zhu Haogu, the same painter whom Bishop White first identified as being responsible for the Paradise of Maitreya, it has been inferred that all three wall paintings in the Bishop White Gallery, both Buddhist and Daoist, might have been executed by the same man or, at least, in the same workshop.<ref name="ROM"/>
The Daoist murals were acquired through the well-known art dealership of [[Yamanaka & Co.]] in 1937. [[Charles Trick Currelly|Charles Currelly]], the founding Director of the ROM, relates in his autobiography how the paintings were offered to the Museum by a certain Mr. Tanaka, who, being particularly impressed by the quality of the Buddhist wall painting already in the ROM's possession, thought it desirable that the pair of Daoist paintings should also come to the ROM, so that there would be in North America at least one complete representation of what these early Northern Chinese temples would have been like.<ref>Currelly, C. I Brought the Ages Home, p. 254. Toronto: Ryerson Press (1990)</ref>
==Design of the Bishop White Gallery==
The Bishop White Gallery is located in the original wing of the ROM, constructed in 1914, where it has remained since the wall paintings were installed in the 1930s. The design of the Gallery, however, has changed dramatically over the years, beginning with a fairly prosaic display of the objects around the circumference of the room, later progressing in the 1980s to a recreation of an authentic temple setting and, since the mid-2000s, receiving a more modern treatment with an 'open concept' layout.
In the early 1980s, the Bishop White Gallery was redesigned to give the effect of a Chinese Buddhist temple of the 14th century. This was not an attempt to reproduce a particular site but rather a thoughtful way of utilizing the space to combine a number of roughly contemporary artefacts into a coherent unit. This was done by imitating a few features of what remains from the Yongle Gong temple complex, long roof beams terminating in curved brackets and a coffered ceiling, together with the same general layout of a rectangular space where devotees could participate in rituals such as meditative circumambulation around a raised altar supporting sculpted images of bodhisattvas. [[File:The Temple Reconstruction, Royal Ontario Museum.jpg|thumb|Temple Statues]] The choice of a temple environment was appropriate not only thematically, since both the wall paintings and the statues were originally used as temple art, but also in terms of the provenance of these artefacts, which originated in geographic proximity to each other in northern China. It might be objected that the contents of this Gallery are not exactly contemporaneous, dating from 1195 to the late 14th century, but yet it would not have been uncommon for a temple to contain devotional objects that its community had accumulated throughout many generations. Although the wall paintings displayed in this 'temple' setting are both Buddhist and Daoist, it was decided that this too would not be inappropriate, because there had long since been a blending of these two religious belief systems. Indeed, from the 10th century onwards the syncretism of Buddhist, Daoist and Confucian beliefs – 'The Three Teachings' - was reflected even in the similarity of artistic style, which is certainly evidenced in the examples presented in the Bishop White Gallery. The renovated Gallery was reputed to be as close as one could come outside China to a major North Chinese monastery hall.<ref>Nagai-Berthrong, E. "The Bishop White Gallery," p. 12, in Rotunda. Toronto: Royal Ontario Museum (Fall 1983)</ref>
==Present Design==
The current incarnation of the Gallery, which opened in 2005, dates from the renovations that were undertaken during the first phase of the 'Renaissance ROM' building project. Several other galleries were also renovated, including the other galleries of the Far Eastern collection, and the construction of the Michael-Lee Chin Crystal, designed by [[Daniel Libeskind]], was completed in 2007. Like the Crystal, the renovation of gallery space in the historic buildings was also intended to be modern in style - quite austere, with a minimum of colour and helpful signage, and an 'open-concept' layout that minimizes visual barriers between adjoining galleries, purportedly so that audience might appreciate the collections as 'works of art,' with little indication of the context for which objects – particularly religious objects – were originally intended.<ref>Ruitenbeek, K. "Light from and for the East: The New East Asian Galleries in the ROM", p.39-44, in Orientations: The Magazine for Collectors and Connoisseurs of Asian Art. (Spring 2006)</ref> That said, the general organization of the artefacts remains much as it was during the Gallery's previous incarnation as a temple reconstruction, with the murals surrounding the wooden sculptures situated in the middle of the space, but the decorative elements of the temple setting have been stripped away to focus one's attention on the objects themselves.
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.5beta)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox document |document_name = Chronicles of the Kings of Mann and the Isles |image = Chronicles of Mann - BL Cotton MS Julius A vii f 31r.jpg |image_width = 200px |image_caption = The first page of the Chronicles of Mann; from BL Cotton MS Julius A. VII, f. 31r |date_created = ca. 1262 |date_ratified = |location_of_document = British Library in London |writer = |signers = |purpose = }} The '''''Chronicles of the Kings of Mann and the Isles'''''<ref name="bl">[http://www.collectbritain.co.uk/dlo.cfm/illuminated/011COTJULA00007U00031000.htm The Years 1016–1030 In The Years In The Chronicles Of The Kings Of Mann And The Isles ('The Manx Chronicle')] – British Library</ref><ref>[http://www.gov.im/lib/news/mnh/chroniclesofmann.xml Chronicles of Mann return ...] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316142100/http://www.gov.im/lib/news/mnh/chroniclesofmann.xml |date=16 March 2012 }} – Isle of Man Government</ref> ({{lang-la|Chronica Regum Manniæ et Insularum}}) or '''Manx Chronicle'''<ref name="bl"/> ([http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?index=0&ref=Cotton_MS_julius_a_vii London, British Library, Cotton MS Julius A. VII, ff. 31r-52r]) is a [[medieval]] [[Latin]] manuscript relating the early history of the [[Isle of Man]].
==Dating== The main part of the manuscript is believed to have been composed and written in 1261 or 1262 at [[Rushen Abbey]] on the island, shortly after the time of the [[Cistercian]] abbey's dedication in 1257, which is the final event retold by the original scribe. The manuscript is written in ink on [[vellum]], with pages roughly {{convert|15|cm|0|abbr=on}} by {{convert|20|cm|0|abbr=on}}.
==Contents== The ''Chronicles'' are a look back, year-by-year from 1016, over the significant events in [[Manx history]] of that time. Written in Latin, it records the island's role as the centre of the [[Norsemen|Norse]] [[Kingdom of Mann and the Isles]], and the influence of its kings and religious leaders, as well as the role of [[Rushen Abbey]] itself – which was founded at the invitation of [[Olaf I Godredsson]], one of the Norse kings. The original scribe also wrote a list of popes (ff. 3r-14r) which ends with [[Pope Urban IV]] (1261–4). It is probable that the ''Chronicles'' were written for the new abbey on its foundation.
Entries for the earlier years are notably shorter than those towards the end of the original section of the manuscript, no doubt due to later events having occurred within living memory of the time of writing, and thus more detail being available. Many of the dates of the earlier annals are put around 15 years earlier than the actual event, and none of these entries before 1047 are directly related to the Isle of Man, having been copied from a source shared with the ''[[Chronicle of Melrose]]''.
Several further notes were later added by the abbey's [[Cistercian monks]], taking the ''Chronicles'' up to 1316. The manuscript also contains a copy of [[Bonizo of Sutri]]'s ''Cronica Romanorum pontificum'' (ff. 15r-30r) and a territorial survey (ff. 53r-54v).<ref name=DM>{{cite web|title=Cotton MS Julius A VII|url=http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?index=0&ref=Cotton_MS_julius_a_vii|work=Digitised Manuscripts|publisher=The British Library|accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref> A record of the bishops of the Western Isles to [[John Dongan|John Donkan]] ([[Bishop of Sodor and Man|Bishop of Man]] and [[Bishop of the Isles|the Isles]] from 1374 to 1387) is appended to the ''Chronicles''.<ref name=DM />
==Provenance== After the abbey was dissolved in 1540 the manuscript is thought to have passed through a number of private hands until being presented by [[Roger Dodsworth]] (d. 1654) to Sir [[Robert Bruce Cotton|Robert Cotton]] (d. 1631) in 1620/1.<ref>{{cite web|title=Humanities Research Institute Online|url=http://www.hrionline.ac.uk/cotton/mss/jul1.htm|publisher=University of Sheffield|accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref> Cotton's collection of medieval and early modern manuscripts was one of the founding collections of the [[British Museum]] and is now cared for by the [[British Library]] in London.
==Repatriation== There have been campaigns to move the ''Chronicles'' permanently to the [[Isle of Man]].
In 2014 it was confirmed that the [[Celtic League]] will be demanding the return of the Chronicles to the [[Isle of Man]].
==Outline== [[File:Chronicles of Mann - BL Cotton MS Julius A vii f 35v.jpg|thumb|The foundation of Rushen Abbey, 1134, in the Chronicles of Mann, from BL Cotton MS Julius A. VII, f. 35v]] * 1016–1030: King [[Canute the Great|Canute]]'s marriage to [[Emma of Normandy|Emma]], the birth of their son [[Harthacanute]], and Canute's journeys to Denmark and Norway. * 1031–1066: Foundation of [[Bury St. Edmunds Abbey]], and the death of Canute. Death of King [[Edward the Confessor]]. * 1066–1079: [[Battle of Stamford Bridge]], [[William I of England|William the Conqueror]]'s victory at the [[Battle of Hastings]]. Conquest of the Isle of Man by [[Godred Crovan]]. * 1079–1098: Foundation of the Cistercian order at [[Cîteaux Abbey|Cîteaux]] in France. * 1102–1152: Commencement of reign of King [[Olaf I of the Isle of Man|Olaf]]. Foundations of [[Savigny Abbey]], [[Furness Abbey]], [[Rievaulx Abbey]], [[Calder Abbey]], [[Melrose Abbey]], and [[Abbeytown|Holme Cultram Abbey]]. Grant of land at Rushen to Furness Abbey by King Olaf. * 1165–1187: Murder of [[Thomas Becket]] at [[Canterbury Cathedral]]. Capture of [[Jerusalem]] by [[Saladin]]. Visit by a [[papal legate]] to the Isle of Man. Marriage of King [[Godred V of the Isle of Man|Godred]], conducted by the Abbot of Rievaulx. * 1228–1237: Death of King Olaf on [[St Patrick's Isle]], and burial at Rushen Abbey. * 1250–1256: Start of reign of King [[Magnus Olafsson|Magnus]] * 1256–1274: Completion of the Abbey Church of St Mary's at Rushen, and dedication by Richard, [[Bishop of Sodor and Man]]. * List of Bishops: A [[list of the Bishops of the Diocese of Sodor and Man]] until [[Simon Orcadensis]], who had died in 1248. The bishop at the time of the writing of the manuscript, Richard, was not included.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Editions and translations== * Broderick, G. (ed. and tr.). ''The Chronicles of the Kings of Mann and the Isles''. 2nd ed. Douglas, 1995. * Munch, P.A. (ed.) and Rev. [[Alexander Goss]] (tr.). ''Chronica regnum Manniae et insularum. The Chronicle of Man and the Sudreys.'' 2 vols. Manx Society 22-3. Douglas, 1874. [http://www.isle-of-man.com/manxnotebook/manxsoc/msvol22/index.htm Available in html]
==External links== {{commonscat|Chronicles of Mann (13th-15th C) - BL Cotton MS Julius A VII|Chronicles of Mann}} *A full digital facsimile of the manuscript is available on the British Library's [http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?index=0&ref=Cotton_MS_julius_a_vii Digitised Manuscripts] website. * Additional photographs are also available on the British Library's Online Gallery. ** [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/illmanus/cottmanucoll/t/011cotjula00007u00031000.html The Years 1016–1030] ** [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/illmanus/cottmanucoll/t/011cotjula00007u00031vr0.html The Years 1031–1066] ** [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/illmanus/cottmanucoll/t/011cotjula00007u00032vr0.html The Years 1066–1079] ** [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/illmanus/cottmanucoll/t/011cotjula00007u00033vr0.html The Years 1079–1098] ** [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/illmanus/cottmanucoll/t/011cotjula00007u00035vr0.html The Years 1102–1152] ** [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/illmanus/cottmanucoll/t/011cotjula00007u00039vr0.html The Years 1165–1187] ** [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/illmanus/cottmanucoll/t/011cotjula00007u00044vr0.html The Years 1228–1237] ** [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/illmanus/cottmanucoll/t/011cotjula00007u00048vr0.html The Years 1250–1256] ** [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/illmanus/cottmanucoll/t/011cotjula00007u00049vr0.html The Years 1256–1274] ** [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/illmanus/cottmanucoll/t/011cotjula00007u00050vr0.html The Bishops of the Church of Sodor] * [http://www.isle-of-man.com/manxnotebook/manxsoc/msvol22/index.htm Text of the Chronicle of Mann] – Manx Society; Latin with English translation
{{Scandinavian Scotland|state=autocollapse}}

page.title: Comparison of software saving Web pages for offline use

revision.comment: /* HTML Content */ added Teleport Pro and friends - tested by time web archiver tool
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=September 2013}} A number of proprietary [[software]] products are available for saving [[Web page]]s for later use [[offline]]. They vary in terms of the techniques used for saving, what types of content can be saved, the format and [[Data compression|compression]] of the saved files, provision for working with already saved content, and in other ways. == HTML Content == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Name !! Technology !! Completeness of saved content !! Support for collections !! Ease of adding to existing collections ! Navigable between saved pages in offline ! Format of saved files; open/proprietary ! Compression ! Notes |- | [[wget]] || [[command line|command line application]] || images and CSS (if -p option is used), but no client-side generated HTML content | Yes | ? | Yes, if -k option is used | Open (HTML or WARC) | Yes, if WARC files are used | |- | [[HTTrack]] || [[command line|command line application]] has WinHTTrack for Windows and WebHTTrack for Linux/BSD/Unix GUI front-ends || ? | ? | ? | Yes. Links all remade so open your locally stored pages for the site you download | Open. Standard HTML pages saved in a folder. Click on index.html to open home page | No | Many options to let you refine what you save. |- | Tenmax's Teleport || windows desktop application and scriptable tools for web crawling and archiving || multimedia (except streaming files), CSS, limited support for javascript events and cookies; shockwave/flash content is downloaded but not crawled | ? | ? | Yes | Open. Standard HTML pages saved in a folder. Click on index.html to open home page | No | supports advanced filtering options and authentication |- | [[ScrapBook]] || [[Firefox extension]] || See note{{refn|group=ScrapBook|Saved content:
Default: * images, CSS and other static content; clientside-generated HTML content—all saved fine Optionally: * sound (MP3, WAV, RAM, WMA) * video (MPG, AVI, MOV, WMV) * archives (ZIP, LZH, RAR, JAR, XPI) * java - but can be problematic * custom document extensions (e.g. PDF)}} | Yes | Easy | Yes IF those pages were saved in scrapbook |Proprietary catalog; regular HTML and content for each page || No || See note{{refn|group=ScrapBook|Extra features: * Search across collections Known issues: * saved pages embedding TED.com presentations (incl. pages on TED.com) cannot be played even when online * selecting a piece of page will save only selected piece — inconvenient when you change page title with a quote from the page * doesn't work with Firefox Quantum at the moment}} |- | [[Mozilla Archive Format]] || Firefox extension || Images, CSS and other static content; clientside-generated HTML content saved fine || Yes || Impossible || No || MAFF (=ZIP of regular HTML and web content) || Always || |- | Read Later Fast || [[Google Chrome extension]] || Stylesheets are saved incompletely or not at all || No || N/A || No || Proprietary; restricted to Google Chrome profile location || No || |- | PageArchiver || Google Chrome extension || Video and audio files (via Flash or HTML5) are not saved || Yes || Yes (import/export features) || No || Open; regular HTML for pages, regular zip file for catalog || Yes for catalog || |- |Archia's Web Page Archiver[http://www.archia.net/ Archia: Web Page Archiver] || E-mail based on-line service || See note{{refn|group=Archia|Saved content:
Images, CSS and other static content, sound (MP3, WAV, RAM, WMA), video (MPG, AVI, MOV, WMV), archives (ZIP, LZH, RAR, JAR, XPI), custom document extensions (e.g. PDF)}} || No || No || No || Open || Yes || |} ==Notes== ===ScrapBook=== {{reflist|group=ScrapBook}} ===Archia=== {{reflist|group=Archia}} == Video == To save video embedded on web sites (e.g. YouTube), there are [[video download extensions]] for Firefox (including Download Helper) and Chrome. == See also == * [[Web annotation#Comparison of web annotation systems|Comparison of web annotation systems]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Software comparisons|Saving Web pages for offline use]] [[Category:Web scraping|*]] {{web-software-stub}}

[[File:0020MAN-Room2.jpg|thumb|365x365px|The {{ill|Hirschfeld Krater|de|Hirschfeld-Krater}}, an example of a krater from the Dipylon cemetery, at the [[National Archaeological Museum, Athens]].]] '''Dipylon kraters''' are [[Geometric art|Geometric Period]] Greek [[terracotta]] funerary vases found at the Dipylon cemetery, near the [[Dipylon Gate]], in [[Kerameikos]], the ancient potters quarter on the northwest side of the ancient city of [[Athens]]. A [[krater]] is a large [[Ancient Greek vase-painting|Ancient Greek painted vase]] used to mix wine and water, but the large kraters at the Dipylon cemetery served as [[Ancient Greek funerary vases|grave markers]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YQsM6U_Iyf0C&pg=PA108&lpg=PA108&dq=dipylon+krater&source=bl&ots=gIiJeI9G9P&sig=rOPYy8AQ6jTel3HEsM1IjjSwh2E&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjgoKaYlPXWAhVJYyYKHSJ5CBY4ChDoAQgwMAI#v=onepage&q=dipylon%20krater&f=false|title=Gardner's Art through the Ages: The Western Perspective|last=Kleiner|first=Fred S.|date=2013-01-01|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=1133954812|language=en}}</ref>
Vases representative of this larger "Dipylon Style," <ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Greek Art and Archaeology|last=Neer|first=Richard|publisher=Thames & Hudson|year=2012|isbn=9780500288771|location=New York|pages=76}}</ref> are housed in the [[National Archaeological Museum, Athens]]<ref>[http://www.namuseum.gr/collections/vases/geom/geometrical04-en.html Α 00990], Attic geometric krater. From Dipylon, Kerameikos. By Hirschfeld Painter. 750-735 B.C.</ref> and the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/248904|title=Attributed to the Hirschfeld Workshop {{!}} Terracotta krater {{!}} Greek, Attic {{!}} Geometric {{!}} The Met|website=The Metropolitan Museum of Art, i.e. The Met Museum|access-date=2017-10-07}}</ref>
== Description of the Dipylon krater in New York == The Met's Dipylon krater is {{convert|43|in|cm}} tall and has a circumference of {{convert|25.5|in|cm}}.<ref name=":0" /> The monumental vase is hollow, with a hole at the bottom, indicating that it was not used as a mixing bowl like regular kraters.<ref name=":1" /> At the Dipylon Cemetery, where it was found, kraters marked the graves of men.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.brown.edu/Departments/Joukowsky_Institute/courses/greekpast/4880.html|title=Dipylon vases|website=www.brown.edu|access-date=2017-10-28}}</ref> Decorations occupy the entire vase, separated into registers containing abstract motifs or figural designs in a dark-on-light style.
A key-patterned meander fills the top registers, while funerary iconography sits below. The figural scenes describe two of the three parts of a proper burial: a prothesis and an ekphora.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/dbag/hd_dbag.htm|title=Death, Burial, and the Afterlife in Ancient Greece {{!}} Essay {{!}} Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History {{!}} The Metropolitan Museum of Art|last=Art|first=Author: Department of Greek and Roman|website=The Met’s Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History|access-date=2017-10-28}}</ref> A prothesis is the laying out of a body for mourning, and an ekphora is the transportation of the body to the grave. The third step in a burial would be the actual burial of the body or its ashes.<ref name=":4" />
The prothesis scene on the Met's Dipylon Krater features standing women with triangular torsos surrounding a prostrate body underneath a checkered burial shroud.<ref name=":1" /> The women raise their arms to their head, tearing out their hair as a sign of mourning for the deceased.<ref name=":3" /> Abstract geometric motifs and animals fill space in between the figures in a dense style characteristic of the Late Geometric Period.<ref name=":1" /> Underneath, the ekphora scene displays warriors with chariots and hourglass-shaped shields transporting the body in a funeral procession.<ref name=":2" />
The horses overlap each other without clear distinctions, in a stiff profile featured across the vase. The elaborate procession, complete with soldiers and horses indicates the importance this family placed on a proper burial,<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=MOORE|first=MARY B.|date=2007|title=ATHENS 803 AND THE EKPHORA|jstor=41321236|journal=Antike Kunst|volume=50|pages=9–23|doi=10.2307/41321236}}</ref> a value also featured in canonical Greek texts like the [[Iliad]].<ref name=":4" /> The similarity of this vase's iconography to that of the Dipylon Amphora, attributed to the same artist, reveals that the rituals displayed were not isolated but were part of a larger tradition of Greek funerary rites in Geometric Period Athens.<ref name=":5" />
<gallery> File:Terracotta krater MET DT360.jpg File:Terracotta krater MET DT258.jpg File:Terracotta krater MET gr14.130.14.AV3.jpg File:Terracotta krater MET gr14.130.14.AV2.jpg File:Terracotta krater MET gr14.130.14.AV1.jpg File:Terracotta krater MET gr14.130.14.R.jpg </gallery>
== See also == * [[Death in ancient Greek art]] * [[Dipylon Amphora]]
== Sources == {{reflist}}
