revision.text:
{{notability|Web|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox dot-com company |name = Parcel2go.com Limited |logo = File:Parcel2Go logo.png |type = [[Private company|Private]] |traded_as = |location = [[Bolton]], [[Lancashire]]{{cite web|title=Price comparison firm Parcel2Go launches crowdfunding bid|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/business/business-news/price-comparison-firm-parcel2go-launches-13867918|website=[[Manchester Evening News]]|accessdate=8 January 2018}} |area served = |key_people = James Greenbury (CEO) |founder = Fil Adams-Mercer
Richard Adams-Mercer
Steven Kramer |industry = Parcel delivery [[Comparison shopping website|comparison website]] |alexa= {{increase}} 20,511 ({{as of|2017|12|20|alt=November 2017}}){{cite web|url=https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/parcel2go.com|title=parcel2go.com Traffic Statistics|publisher=[[Alexa Internet]]|accessdate=15 November 2017}} |products = |native clients = |homepage = [https://www.parcel2go.com/ www.parcel2go.com] |foundation = }} '''Parcel2Go''' is a British parcel delivery [[Comparison shopping website|comparison website]] offering customers the ability to compare both domestic and worldwide postage options from a range of providers.{{cite web|title=Can Parcel2Go, the MoneySuperMarket for parcels, be the UK's next £100m company?|url=http://www.londonlovesbusiness.com/entrepreneurs/fast-growing-businesses-and-sme/can-parcel2go-the-moneysupermarket-for-parcels-be-the-uks-next-100m-company/6875.article|website=Londonlovesbusiness.com|accessdate=15 November 2017}} The company was founded by father and son Fil and Richard Adams-Mercer together with colleague Steven Kramer.{{cite web|title=Parcel2Go reveals record turnover|url=http://postandparcel.info/33358/news/parcel2go-reveals-record-turnover/|website=Post & Parcel|accessdate=15 November 2017}} In September 2017 the Parcel2Go merged with National Pallets.{{cite web|title=Parcel2Go merge with National Pallets|url=https://tamebay.com/2017/09/parcel2go-merge-national-pallets.html|website=tamebay.com|accessdate=15 November 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|https://www.parcel2go.com/}} {{UK postal system}} [[Category:Postal system of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Comparison shopping websites]]

revision.comment: /* Xanth series */ updated books in progress per hipiers newsletter
revision.text:
This is a partial '''list of works by [[Piers Anthony]]'''. Anthony has published 166 works in total from 1956 to December 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hipiers.com/bibliography.html|title=Bibliography|author=Piers Anthony|accessdate=15 Feb 2014}}</ref>
==Fiction== ===Novels=== ====''Aton''/''Worlds of Chthon'' series==== The series is continued by [[Charles Platt (author)|Charles Platt]] with Anthony's permission # ''[[Chthon (novel)|Chthon]]'' (1967) Anthony's first published novel; nominated for the [[Hugo Award|Hugo]] and [[Nebula Award]]s # ''Phthor'' (1975)
====''[[Battle Circle]]'' series==== # ''Sos the Rope'' (1968) # ''Var the Stick'' (1972) # ''Neq the Sword'' (1975) Books 1-3 were omnibused as ''Battle Circle'' (1978)
====''[[Of Man and Manta]]'' series<ref name="mundania">Published by [http://www.mundania.com/ Mundania Press]</ref>==== # ''Omnivore'' (1968) # ''Orn'' (1970) # ''0X'' (1976) Note: title is commonly listed as ''OX'' ("oh-ex"), but should be ''0X'' ([[Arabic numerals|Arabic]] [[0 (number)|zero]]·[[Roman numerals|Roman]] [[10 (number)|ten]]). (Chapter16: "I am speaking for 0X," the computer said. "This is the code designation Zero X, or Arabic numeral nothing multiplied by the Roman numeral ten, ...") Books 1-3 were omnibused as ''Of Man and Manta'' (1986)
====''Jason Striker'' series (with Roberto Fuentes)==== # ''Kiai!'' (1974) # ''Mistress of Death'' (1974) # ''Bamboo Bloodbath'' (1974) # ''Ninja's Revenge'' (1975) # ''Amazon Slaughter'' (1976) # ''Curse of the Ninja'' (2001)
====''[[Xanth]]'' series==== Anthony's most extensive series, with 41 novels and growing. # ''[[A Spell for Chameleon]]'' (1977) # ''[[The Source of Magic]]'' (1979) # ''[[Castle Roogna]]'' (1979) # ''[[Centaur Aisle]]'' (1982) # ''[[Ogre, Ogre]]'' (1982) "Ogre, Ogre" was the first paperback original fantasy novel to appear on the New York Times Bestseller List. # ''[[Night Mare]]'' (1983) # ''[[Dragon on a Pedestal]]'' (1983) # ''[[Crewel Lye]]'' (1984) # ''[[Golem in the Gears]]'' (1986) # ''[[Vale of the Vole]]'' (1987) # ''[[Heaven Cent]]'' (1988) # ''[[Man from Mundania]]'' (1989) # ''[[Isle of View]]'' (1990) # ''[[Question Quest]]'' (1991) # ''[[The Color of Her Panties]]'' (1992) # ''[[Demons Don't Dream]]'' (1992) # ''[[Harpy Thyme]]'' (1993) # ''[[Geis of the Gargoyle]]'' (1994) # ''[[Roc and a Hard Place]]'' (1995) # ''[[Yon Ill Wind]]'' (1996) # ''[[Faun & Games]]'' (1997) # ''[[Zombie Lover]]'' (1998) # ''[[Xone of Contention]]'' (1999) # ''[[The Dastard]]'' (2000) # ''[[Swell Foop]]'' (2001) # ''[[Up in a Heaval]]'' (2002) # ''[[Cube Route]]'' (2003) # ''[[Currant Events]]'' (2004) # ''[[Pet Peeve (novel)|Pet Peeve]]'' (2005) # ''[[Stork Naked]]'' (2006) # ''[[Air Apparent]]'' (2007) # ''[[Two to the Fifth]]'' (2008) # ''[[Jumper Cable]]'' (2009) # ''[[Knot Gneiss]]'' (2010) # ''[[Well-Tempered Clavicle]]'' (2011) # ''[[Luck of the Draw (novel)|Luck of the Draw]]'' (2012) # ''[[Esrever Doom]]'' (2013) # ''[[Board Stiff]]'' (2013) # ''[[Five Portraits]]'' (2014) # ''[[Isis Orb]]'' (2016) # ''[[Ghost Writer in the Sky]]'' (2017) # ''[[Fire Sail]]'' (in publisher queue) # ''[[Jest Right]]'' (in publisher queue) # ''[[Skeleton Key]]'' (in progress) # ''[[A Tryst of Fate]]'' (planned) Books 1-3 were omnibussed as ''[[The Magic of Xanth]]'' (1981) // ''[[Three Complete Xanth Novels]]'' / ''[[The Quest for Magic]]'' Books 4-6 were omnibussed as ''[[The Continuing Xanth Saga]]''
====[[Cluster (novels)|''Cluster'']] series==== # ''Cluster'' (1977; also known as ''Vicinity Cluster'' in UK edition) # ''Chaining the Lady'' (1978) # ''Kirlian Quest'' (1978) # ''Thousandstar'' (1980) # ''Viscous Circle'' (1982)
====[[Tarot (novel)|''Tarot'']] series==== This was originally written as single novel in continuity with the ''Cluster'' series, which takes place decades later, but was split up due to length at the behest of the publisher, Jove.<ref>Tarot Introduction, page XV</ref> * ''God of Tarot'' (1979) * ''Vision of Tarot'' (1980) * ''Faith of Tarot'' (1980) * ''Tarot'' (1987) The series omnibus as a single novel as originally intended
====''[[Apprentice Adept]]'' series==== # ''Split Infinity'' (1980) # ''Blue Adept'' (1981) # ''Juxtaposition'' (1982) # ''Out of Phaze'' (1987) # ''Robot Adept'' (1988) # ''Unicorn Point'' (1989) # ''Phaze Doubt'' (1990) Books 1-3 were omnibussed as ''[[Double Exposure (Piers Anthony)|Double Exposure]]'' (1982)
====''[[Incarnations of Immortality]]'' series==== # ''[[On a Pale Horse]]'' (1983) # ''[[Bearing an Hourglass]]'' (1984) # ''[[With a Tangled Skein]]'' (1985) # ''[[Wielding a Red Sword]]'' (1986) # ''[[Being a Green Mother]]'' (1987) # ''[[For Love of Evil]]'' (1988) # ''[[And Eternity]]'' (1990) # ''[[Under a Velvet Cloak]]''<ref name="mundania"/> (2007) Book 1-2 were omnibussed as ''[[Incarnations of Immortality]]'' (2013)
====''[[Bio of a Space Tyrant]]'' series==== # ''Refugee'' (1983) # ''Mercenary'' (1984) # ''Politician'' (1985) # ''Executive'' (1985) # ''Statesman'' (1986) # ''The Iron Maiden'' (2001)
====''The Adventures of Kelvin of Rud'' series==== <ref name="mundania"/> # ''Dragon's Gold'' (1987) with Robert E. Margroff # ''Serpent's Silver'' (1988) with Robert E. Margroff # ''Chimaera's Copper'' (1990) with Robert E. Margroff # ''Orc's Opal'' (1990) with Robert E. Margroff # ''Mouvar's Magic'' (1992) with Robert E. Margroff Books 1-3 were omnibussed as ''[[Across the Frames]]'' (1992), and as ''[[Three Complete Novels]]'' (1994) Books 4-5 were omnibussed as ''[[Final Magic]]'' (1992)
====[[Pornucopia (novel)|''Pornucopia'']] series==== <ref name="mundania"/> # ''Pornucopia'' (1989) # ''The Magic Fart'' (2003) Books 1-2 were omnibussed as ''[[The Pornucopia Compendium]]'' (2015)
====[[Mode series|''Mode'']] series==== # ''Virtual Mode'' (1991) # ''Fractal Mode'' (1992) # ''Chaos Mode'' (1993) # ''DoOon Mode'' (2001)
====''[[Geodyssey]]'' series==== # ''Isle of Woman'' (1993) # ''Shame of Man'' (1994) # ''Hope of Earth'' (1997) # ''Muse of Art'' (1999) # ''Climate of Change'' (2010)
====[[ChroMagic series|''ChroMagic'']] series<ref name="mundania"/>==== # ''Key to Havoc'' (2002) # ''Key to Chroma'' (2003) # ''Key to Destiny'' (2004) # ''Key to Liberty'' (2007) # ''Key to Survival'' (2008)
====''Metal Maiden'' series==== * ''To Be a Woman'' (2014)<ref name="goodreads">{{cite web | url=http://www.goodreads.com/series/101302-the-metal-maiden-series | title=The Metal Maiden Series | publisher=[[Goodreads]] | accessdate=2013-09-04}}</ref> * ''Shepherd'' (2014)<ref name="goodreads"/> * ''Fly Trap'' (2014)<ref name="goodreads"/> * ''Awares'' (2014)<ref name="goodreads"/>
====''Aliena'' series==== # ''[[Aliena]]'' (2013) # ''[[Aliena Too]]'' (2014)
====Other==== * ''The Ring'' (1968) with Robert E. Margroff * [[Macroscope (novel)|''Macroscope'']]<ref name="mundania"/> (1969) 1970 [[Hugo Award for Best Novel]] nomination. The UK edition (Sphere) was cut by about 25%. * ''Hasan'' (1969; 1977 revised) * ''The E.S.P. Worm'' (1970) with Robert E. Margroff * ''[[Prostho Plus]]'' (1971) * ''Race Against Time'' (1973) * ''Rings of Ice'' (1974) * ''Triple Détente'' (1974) * ''Steppe'' (1976) * ''But What of Earth?'' (1976: "collaboration" with [[Robert Coulson]]; 1989: Anthony's original republished, with annotations) see [[Piers Anthony|main article]]. * ''Pretender'' (1979) with Frances Hall, {{ISBN|0-89370-130-0}} * ''Mute'' (1981) a sequel named "Moot" was shelved, with extensive notes. Those notes are now lost and that sequel will not be written. * ''Shade of the Tree'' (1986) * [[Ghost (Piers Anthony novel)|''Ghost'']] (1986) * ''Total Recall'' (1989) a novelization of the film ''[[Total Recall (1990 film)|Total Recall]]'', which is based on the short story "[[We Can Remember It For You Wholesale]]" by [[Philip K. Dick]]. The UK and US editions are different. * ''Through the Ice'' (1989) with Robert Kornwise posthumously—Kornwise was a high school student who had died. His friends sent his unfinished manuscript and a plea to Piers Anthony to help their deceased friend get published. To make sure that the book was a fitting memorial tribute, Piers Anthony made sure it was printed on acid-free paper despite the expense. * ''Firefly'' (1990) * ''Hard Sell'' (1990) * ''Dead Morn'' (1990) with Roberto Fuentes * ''Balook'' (1991) * ''MerCycle'' (1991) * ''[[Tatham Mound]]'' (1991) * ''The Caterpillar's Question'' (1992) with [[Philip José Farmer]]—This collaboration was actually the result of another proposed collaborative project. The original idea proposed by an editor was to have a book where each chapter was written by a different author. That project fell apart, but Piers Anthony and Philip José Farmer later decided they wanted to salvage something from it by morphing it into a two-person collaboration, where the two alternated chapters, without revealing who wrote which chapters. * ''[[Killobyte]]'' (1993) * ''If I Pay Thee Not in Gold'' (1993) with [[Mercedes Lackey]] * ''Volk'' (1996) historical fiction that is atypical for Anthony * ''The Willing Spirit'' (1996) with Alfred Tella * ''Spider Legs'' (1998) with [[Clifford A. Pickover]] * ''Quest for the Fallen Star'' (1998) with James Richey and Alan Riggs * ''Dream a Little Dream'' (1998) with Julie Brady * ''Realty Check'' (1999) * ''The Secret of Spring'' (2000) with Jo Anne Taeusch * ''The Gutbucket Quest'' (2000) with Ron Leming * ''Starkweather: Immortal 0'' (2007) with [[David A. Rodriguez]]—This collaboration is a different one for Piers Anthony. He crafted an original short story based on the character Cartaphilus from the creator-owned ''[[Starkweather (comics)|Starkweather]]'' comic book series by David A. Rodriguez. This short story was then adapted into a comic book script and painted by fantasy artist [[Patrick McEvoy]] and published by [[Archaia Studios]], making ''Starkweather: Immortal'' issue 0, Piers Anthony's first true comic book work. * ''Tortoise Reform''<ref name="mundania"/> (2007) * ''The Sopaths'' (2011) * ''Eroma'' (2011) * ''Hair Power'' (2016) from Dreaming Big Publications * ''Writer's Retweet'' (2016) from Dreaming Big Publications * Captive (2016) from eXcessica Publishing * Jack and the Giants (2014) with J.R. Rain from Rain Press * Dragon Assassin (2013) with J.R. Rain * Dolfin Tayle with J.R. Rain * LavaBull with J.R. Rain * Noah's Brick * Odd Exam * Pandora Park * Pira * Service Goat
===Short story collections=== * ''Anthonology'' (1985) * ''Alien Plot'' (1992) * ''Lava'' from the ''Chronology'' Anthology (2015) published by [https://curiosityquills.com Curiosity Quills Press] * ''In The Shadow of The Song'' from the ''Darkscapes'' Anthology (2017) published by [https://curiosityquills.com Curiosity Quills Press]
====''Relationships'' series==== # ''Relationships'' (2006) republished in 2007 by [http://www.phaze.com Phaze Books] # ''Relationships, Vol. 2'' (2007) published by [http://www.phaze.com Phaze Books] # ''Relationships, Vol. 3'' (2008) published by [http://www.phaze.com Phaze Books] # ''Relationships 4'' (2010) published by [http://www.phaze.com Phaze Books]
==Nonfiction== * ''Bio of an Ogre'' (1988) the autobiography of Piers Anthony to age 50 * ''[[Letters to Jenny]]'' (1994)—The mother of a teenage fan wrote to Piers Anthony about her daughter Jenny, the victim of a drunk driver, being paralyzed and in a coma. The mother felt that having letters from Jenny's favorite author read to her might help bring her out of her coma. He wrote her constantly and for a long period of time, even naming a Xanth character after her. Jenny eventually came out of her coma, but remains paralyzed and has difficulty communicating. This book is a collection of the letters from the first year of correspondence. * ''How Precious was that While'' (2001) an autobiography to age 65 * ''Alfred'' (2007) a biography of the author's father Alfred Jacob as told by the women in his father's life
==Related works== * ''Cut By Emerald'' (1987) by Dana Kramer, a Combat Command [[game book]] set in the ''[[Bio of a Space Tyrant]]'' universe. * ''Encyclopedia of Xanth'' (1987) by [[Jody Lynn Nye]], a Crossroads Adventure [[game book]] set in the ''[[Xanth]]'' universe. * ''Piers Anthony's Visual Guide to Xanth'' (Harper, 1989), by Piers Anthony and Jody Lynn Nye. Illustrated by Todd Cameron Hamilton and James Clouse. {{ISBN|0-380-75749-4}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.hipiers.com/bibliography.html Piers Anthony's Bibliography List] * [http://us.macmillan.com/author/piersanthony Piers Anthony's work at Macmillan.com] * {{isfdb name|4|Piers Anthony}} * [http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/a/piers-anthony/ Piers Anthony] at Fantastic Fiction * {{Worldcat id|lccn-n79-7249|Piers Anthony}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Anthony, Piers}} [[Category:Bibliographies by writer]] [[Category:Bibliographies of British writers]] [[Category:Bibliographies of American writers]] [[Category:Science fiction bibliographies]]
